name: NPR
text:
Mei Xiang, a panda at the National Zoo, could be having a cub soon. Veterinarians found what appear to be fetal tissue during an ultrasound.

"In the middle of a pandemic, this is a joyful moment we can all get excited about," said the chief veterinarian.
https://t.co/q0v9CcdSLA

name: NPR
text: Kenya's elephant population has more than doubled since the 1980s, and one national park is currently having a 'baby boom' thanks to a relief from drought ‚Äî and the country's efforts to stop poachers. https://t.co/vUvI2wxEJF

name: NPR
text:
The success of Emi Mahmoud's slam poem "Mama" turned her into an international public figure. Since then, she's presented at the UN, joined White House round-table discussions with Obama and given TED Talks. 

Her next big goal? A career in medicine.
https://t.co/4cxYjQsoRH

name: NPR
text: The White House said President Trump's younger brother, Robert Trump, died on Saturday. https://t.co/ysZA7hU3lN

name: NPR
text:
When Jackie Summers launched Sorel Liqueur in 2011, he was the first Black person in the U.S. to hold a license to make liquor. 

‚ÄúThe entry to market is designed to be almost impenetrable,‚Äù he says. @hereandnow https://t.co/MIlIWCedxF

name: NPR
text:
In 2012, Kathleen Edwards gave up music and opened a cafe called Quitters Coffee. Now, after taking time to heal, she's back.

"I saved so much money in therapists in the first 20 years of my life as a songwriter, I just used it as my outlet," she says.
https://t.co/pykKSUXpue

name: NPR
text: Israel and the United Arab Emirates have agreed to forge a path toward normal diplomatic relations. Israel says as part of the agreement it will suspend its controversial plans to annex more territory in the West Bank. https://t.co/wL1N4vNU4i

name: NPR
text:
Jackson Ingalls was born into a basketball family. His mom won five state tournament titles as a coach. His dad played Division II basketball. 

But Jackson‚Äôs path looks a whole lot different.

‚ÄúSince he was 10 he was saying, ‚ÄòI'm gonna ref for the NBA.‚Äô ‚Äù https://t.co/6wDiK1uizs

name: NPR
text:
Denmark's so-called "ghetto package" aims to rid the country of immigrant-heavy areas by 2030. Fearing eviction, some residents are suing the government for what they view as blatant discrimination.
https://t.co/wfM1QbFC4Z

name: NPR
text: Jacob Collier, the 26-year-old Grammy-winning multi-instrumental composer and prodigy, spoke to NPR about his new album, Djesse Vol. 3., which features collaborations with Ty Dolla $ign and T-Pain. https://t.co/VRqyAOIAz5

name: NPR
text:
Madeleine Ryan was diagnosed with autism while she was writing her new novel. She says creating her main character helped her embrace the way she process her own thoughts and feelings. 

"It was a very intimate adventure, writing this book."
https://t.co/gQYbbYHavu

name: NPR
text: "This is the first time in my experience of studying elections that there's a genuine fear that the postal system will be manipulated in a subversive way," said one expert. https://t.co/y2bsRszo1j

name: NPR
text:
When reporting from the border, Jean Guerrero says she became fascinated with how Stephen Miller ‚Äî a descendant of Jewish refugees ‚Äî became the architect of Trump's "harshest rhetoric and policies, targeting people ... like his own great-grandparents." 
https://t.co/xxsTL1yNi5

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: The (all-virtual) Democratic National Convention starts tomorrow. 

Here's what you need to know: https://t.co/VRA3pJtmqR

name: NPR
text: Former deputy postmaster general:  ‚ÄúI believe it is highly likely ... the absentee ballots of at least tens of thousands of voters will arrive at election offices after Election Day and will not be counted unless the Ballot Receipt Deadline is extended." https://t.co/MLa9fyPecC

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: The U.S. Postal Service confirms to NPR that it's postponing the removal of mailboxes for the next 90 days‚Ä¶ https://t.co/ZefY5wBQzk

name: NPR
text:
Just six months ago, Biden's campaign seemed all but over. Now, he has an 11-point lead over the incumbent president, according to the latest NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll.

Here's how he got to this point üëá
https://t.co/OrOZQ0wtem

name: NPR
text:
George Floyd.
Breonna Taylor.
Ahmaud Arbery.

In Part 1 of a 3-part special, NPR looks back at how before their faces appeared on signs and their names became singular chants, Floyd, Taylor and Arbery lived full lives with hopes and dreams and aspirations. https://t.co/IIbEnNuDx4

name: NPR
text:
A Japanese cargo ship that ran aground off the coast of Mauritius has split in two. It spilled at least 1,000 tons of oil into the Indian Ocean ‚Äî causing what scientists call the worst ecological disaster in the country's history.
https://t.co/Ba7vKj1D9b

name: NPR
text:
Stephen Miller "has his hands on the pulse of Trump's most violent voting base because ... he's been reading white supremacist and neo-Nazi literature for such a long time," reporter Jean Guerrero tells NPR. 
https://t.co/2oksDIn9r5

name: NPR
text:
The director of the CDC says if Americans don't follow public health guidance, the country could be facing "the worst fall, from a public health perspective, we've ever had."
https://t.co/ng7NSJqTFB

name: NPR
text:
‚ÄúWe actually wanted to shift even the verbiage from ‚Äòdistance learning‚Äô to ‚Äòconnecting through crisis‚Äô because primarily we wanted our students to experience connection,‚Äù says one middle school principal.  
 https://t.co/ekBXJdYpAP

name: NPR
text:
Bike shops across the country are reporting increased demand as the pandemic changes the way people get around. One family-owned shop in Chicago ‚Äî with three levels of retail space ‚Äî is almost empty.
https://t.co/sPyPkUtiJI
